shared_text:
City of Groveport
August 20 at 8:18 AM ·

THROWBACK THURSDAY!!!
This is Groveport Madison High School’s Cruiser Stadium and its original natural grass surface as it looked in 1970. Note the small wooden bleachers that once sat on the visitors’ side of the field as well as the small, white wagon in the upper center of the photo that served as a concession stand. Also, the running track that is now in Cruiser Stadium was not originally part of the facility, so the home bleachers were much closer to the field back then. The stadium in those days was surrounded by farm fields. (Photo courtesy of the Groveport Heritage Museum.)

If you have a child in kindergarten through twelfth grade in your household who was receiving free or reduced-price meals while in school, your child is eligible for the Pandemic-Electronic Benefit Transfer (P-EBT) program to receive Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP) benefits as a result of the school closure.

The federal Families First Coronavirus Response Act of 2020 provides a temporary program called Pandemic-Electronic Benefit Transfer (P-EBT). P-EBT provides children in kindergarten through twelfth grade eligible for free or reduced-price meals with Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP, formerly known as food stamps) benefits. The program is administered by the Ohio Department of Job and Family Services and the Department is partnering with the Ohio Department of Education (ODE) to ensure children and families receive this important benefit.

For questions regarding P-EBT, please contact the ODJFS customer service line at 1-866-244-007, or you can call Dan Magee in our Food Services office, at 614-836-4969.
#igtbac

Teaching and learning will continue just as it was before spring break. Our teachers will continue to provide challenging, creative, and differentiated assignments so that our students get the best possible education we can provide. It’s important to emphasize that students still need to complete their daily assignments. The completion of this work documents their attendance and the work is being recorded and graded by our teachers.

Grab & Go meal service will continue on Mondays and Wednesdays, from 11:30 a.m. until 12:30 p.m., at our 13 locations.

The Children's Hunger Alliance (CHA) and State Senator Tina Maharath recognized Groveport Madison Schools for the implementation of a universal free breakfast program. With the launch of this program, all students can get a free, tasty, and nutritionally-balanced breakfast every day. Elementary and middle school students eat breakfast right in their classroom as soon they arrive at school.

Thanks to CHA, the District was able to secure grants to offset most of the start-up costs for the program and federal reimbursement covers nearly all of the food and operational expenses.

The program was started as a result of Middle School North Teacher Jill Hetki. Jill began serving breakfast in her classroom on her own, beginning in 2018. Her commitment and love for her students began an effort that benefits nearly 6,000 students every day.

Chartwells K12, the District's food services provider, has launched a program to get our high school students' input into what they want to see on the lunch menus. Chartwell's "Student Choice" program encourages students to try a free sample of two different selections (this week it was marsala chicken wings from Chaat House, versus a chicken eggroll from Bok Choy). This week's winner was . . . the chicken eggroll, capturing 76% of the vote! The Bok Choy chicken egg roll will now be added to the student's lunch menu.

We also will be launching the program at the elementary and middle schools in the very near future.

Please join the City of Groveport for this fun and FREE event.
